meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> stuff to a <radical>river</radical>, giving it <kanji>instruction</kanji>. This river is a new river so it needs you to say things, giving it instruction on what to do. Otherwise the river wouldn’t know how to behave.
The <radical>bow</radical> radical and the <kanji>bow</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!

You see a <radical>slide</radical> covered in <radical>dirt</radical> and use your <radical>mouth</radical> to clean it off. Then, you <kanji>announce</kanji> to everyone that the slide is clean and they can use it safely again.

If a <radical>grain</radical> seems extra <radical>heavy</radical>, you know it's a different <kanji>kind</kanji>. Not all <kanji>type</kanji>s of grains are the same. So when you feel the heavy type, you know it isn't the same as the light kind.

You ride your scooter through the dirt while carrying a sheep because you're determined to attain something. Greatness? Glory? Everlasting fame? Maybe you'll attain a plural combination of all those things. After all, you are the best sheep-carrying off-road scooterist the world has ever seen.

The <radical>rice</radical> you feed to a <radical>big</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical> can be of any <kanji>type</kanji>, <kanji>kind</kanji>, or <kanji>category</kanji>. It doesn't matter what kind of rice it is, the big geoduck will eat it.

You want to share <radical>happiness</radical> with people so you <radical>stamp</radical> <radical>stool</radical>s with the <kanji>news</kanji>. Now when people want a <kanji>report</kanji> of all the happy things going on, they can just look down before they sit.

The <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>temple</radical> is <kanji>equal</kanji> to all of the other non-bamboo temples. Just because it's made of bamboo doesn't make it any less special and spiritual.

The water from a <radical>tsunami</radical> can create a lot of <radical>energy</radical> when made into <kanji>steam</kanji>. Steam power used to be all the rage back in the day. Steam comes from water, water comes from tsunamis, so logically, tsunamis are a great source of energy.
Your <radical>leader</radical> from <radical>long ago</radical> thought to <kanji>borrow</kanji> something precious from you. This leader did not return the thing he borrowed, and now he will pay.

In a dangerous <radical>fire</radical>, a <radical>gambler</radical> will always try to <kanji>bake</kanji> something before fleeing to safety. It could be his own house on fire, and the gambler would still use the free heat source to get some baking done. Maybe he's gambling that those baked goods will offset the cost of a new home…

This kanji also means <kanji>burn</kanji>, because that's what happens when you expose something to a lot of heat.

Under a <radical>canopy</radical>, there are two <radical>person</radical>s on the <radical>dirt</radical>. What do they do there? They <kanji>sit</kanji>. The people use the dirt under the canopy as a <kanji>seat</kanji> for their butts.

The <radical>death</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical> will cause you to <kanji>forget</kanji> all of the most important things. People think memories are kept in your brain, but that's not true. Your heart is where all of your most precious memories are kept, and when it dies, you forget them all.

A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>previous</radical>ly gave everything in this town a good <kanji>wash</kanji>. There are many laundromats in this town, so when the previous tsunami hit, all of the detergent mixed with the water and gave everything a good wash.

In a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>prison</radical>, there lies a <radical>treasure chest</radical> containing a golden <kanji>chest</kanji> piece. This mighty chest armor will grant you protection from nearly any attack, because it is imbued with moon magic.

Nestled in the light of the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>grass</radical> is a <radical>treasure chest</radical> that you can see with your <kanji>brain</kanji>. You close your eyes, and you can see the spot, but it's kept deep in your brain, and you have to use its power to find it.
A religious <radical>leader</radical> wearing a <radical>mask</radical> could be either a <kanji>monk</kanji> or a <kanji>priest</kanji>. You don’t know, their face is covered by a mask!

You want your <radical>spirit</radical> to be <radical>simple</radical> so you practice <kanji>Zen Buddhism</kanji>. Zen is all about meditating and letting earthly things go. There's nothing more simple for your spirit than being <kanji>Zen</kanji>.

With a <radical>lip ring</radical>, anything is <kanji>possible</kanji>. Having a lip ring grants you the power to conquer any obstacle, achieve any goal. As long as it's a <kanji>passable</kanji> lip ring, that is. If it isn't good enough, it isn't possible to be passable.

<radical>Say</radical> it at <radical>noon</radical>. That's the only time I will <kanji>allow</kanji> you to say it. That's the only time I will <kanji>permit</kanji> you to say it. Other than that, no saying anything. Noon is your window.

A <radical>tree</radical> that's been sliced up in <radical>winter</radical> can be used as a <kanji>flat object counter</kanji>. Since it's winter, all the leaves have fallen off the tree, so it's easy to cut into slats. These slats can be used as counters for flat objects.

Within the <radical>blue</radical> water, a <radical>conflict</radical> stirs, but is made <kanji>quiet</kanji> by the muffling power of liquid. Under this blue water is a great conflict between two sea monsters, but on the surface it appears peaceful and quiet as the water prevents sound from rising above the surface.
The <radical>paragraph</radical> radical and the <kanji>paragraph</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
Killing two <radical>tree</radical>s with a <radical>jackhammer</radical> is expressly <kanji>prohibit</kanji>ed. Don't get me wrong, you can rip up one tree with your jackhammer, but not two.

In your <radical>mouth</radical> you put your <radical>life</radical> on the line by putting in a <radical>sword</radical> that is <radical>big</radical>. You put it all the way down there, so you <kanji>consume</kanji> it.

If you have a <radical>fire</radical> and a <radical>helicopter</radical> hovering beside it, there's going to be a lot of <radical>dirt</radical> and <kanji>smoke</kanji> billowing around. Mostly smoke, on account of the fire. Now it's in your eyes and mouth. It gets in your lungs and you can't breathe. Why, helicopter, why!

Into your <radical>mouth</radical> the <radical>leader</radical> shot an <radical>arrow</radical> with an attached <radical>hook</radical> so that they'd be able to see into your <kanji>throat</kanji>.

On your <radical>mouth</radical> is a <radical>stamp</radical> that you <kanji>tap</kanji>, <kanji>strike</kanji> and <kanji>slap</kanji> to create a beat! The stamp looks like a little drum, but you're really just hitting your mouth for fun (the stamp was an excuse to make it seem normal).
What do you <radical>eat</radical> like a <radical>machine</radical>? <kanji>Candy</kanji>!
Using <radical>flowers</radical> to make a <radical>lip ring</radical> is always going to end in <kanji>frustration</kanji>.
You've got a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>weapon</radical>, and some <radical>thread</radical> lying around. So of course you decide to <kanji>connect</kanji> them all together.
